question:
Who built the famous Jama Masjid of Delhi?

RAS/RTS (Pre), 1997
solution:
• The Jama Masjid of Delhi, one of the largest and most renowned mosques in India, was built by Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan.
  • Its construction began in 1650 CE and was completed in 1656 CE.
  • Shah Jahan commissioned the mosque as part of his new capital city, Shahjahanabad (now Old Delhi).
  • The mosque was originally called Masjid-i-Jahan Numa, meaning “Mosque that reflects the world.”
  • It is built in red sandstone and white marble, showcasing classic Mughal architectural style.

Additional Information:

  • Humayun and Ibrahim Lodi ruled before the architectural zenith of the Mughal Empire and were not associated with this mosque.
  • Akbar built several mosques, but not the Jama Masjid of Delhi.
  • Jama Masjid is located near Red Fort, another major structure built by Shah Jahan.

question:
The Upanishads were translated into Persian during the reign of which Mughal emperor?

UPPSC (Pre), 1992, 2009; UPPSC (Mains), 2006
solution:
• The Upanishads were translated into Persian during the reign of Mughal Emperor Shahjahan.
  • This translation project was undertaken by Dara Shikoh, Shahjahan’s eldest son, who had a deep interest in Hindu philosophy and mysticism.
  • Dara Shikoh translated the Upanishads into Persian under the title "Sirr-e-Akbar" (The Great Secret) around 1657 CE.
  • He believed that the essence of Vedantic philosophy was in harmony with Islamic Sufism.
  • His work was instrumental in introducing Indian spiritual thought to the Islamic and later European world.

Additional Information:

  • Aurangzeb, Dara’s brother, was orthodox and opposed to such syncretic efforts.
  • Akbar promoted interfaith dialogue but did not oversee the translation of the Upanishads specifically.
  • Humayun had little direct involvement in religious translations during his short and unstable reign.

question:
Under which title did Dara Shikoh translate the Upanishads into Persian?

UP Lower Sub (SPL) (Pre), 2004; UPPSC (Pre), 2000
solution:
• Dara Shikoh, the eldest son of Mughal emperor Shah Jahan, translated the Upanishads into Persian.
  • The title of this translation was "Sirr-e-Akbar", which means "The Great Secret".
  • He undertook this work to explore the spiritual unity between Hinduism and Islam, especially linking Vedanta philosophy with Sufism.
  • Dara believed the Upanishads contained the core essence of monotheism, aligning with his mystic vision.
  • This translation later helped European scholars access Indian spiritual texts through further translations from Persian.

Additional Information:

  • Majma-ul-Bahrain was another famous work by Dara Shikoh, discussing the confluence of Hindu and Islamic philosophies.
  • Kitab-ul-Bayan and Al-Fihrist are unrelated to the Upanishad translations.

question: Which Mughal emperor abolished the court custom 'Sijda' started by Balban?
solution:
• The court custom of 'Sijda' involved prostration before the emperor, introduced in the Delhi Sultanate by Balban and later revived by Mughal Emperor Akbar.
  • Akbar included ‘Sijda’ and ‘Paibos’ (kissing the feet) as part of his imperial court rituals, influenced by Persian traditions to elevate the emperor's status as a divine ruler.
  • However, Shahjahan, though a powerful emperor, was more orthodox than Akbar and abolished the practice of Sijda as it was seen as un-Islamic.
  • He replaced it with more Islamically acceptable forms of salutation, emphasizing his adherence to Sunni orthodoxy.
  • This change reflected a shift from Akbar’s syncretic policies to a more conservative Islamic orientation.

Additional Information:

  • Aurangzeb, even more orthodox, strictly prohibited such rituals.
  • Jahangir maintained most of Akbar's court traditions, including Sijda.
  • The abolition of Sijda under Shahjahan shows the gradual return to Islamic conservatism in later Mughal rule.

question:
Who gifted the famous 'Kohinoor Diamond' to Shah Jahan?

UPPSC (Mains), 2015
option_4: Abul Hasan Qutb Shah
solution:
• The Kohinoor Diamond, one of the most famous diamonds in the world, came into Shah Jahan’s possession during his reign.
  • It was presented to Shah Jahan by Mir Jumla, whose full name was Muhammad Saeed Mir Jumla.
  • Mir Jumla was a diamond merchant from Iran, who later became a governor and general under Aurangzeb.
  • He gifted the Kohinoor to Shah Jahan during his earlier career when he sought imperial patronage in the Mughal court.
  • The diamond originally belonged to the Golconda mines in the Deccan, ruled by the Qutb Shahi dynasty.

Additional Information:

  • Aurangzeb did not gift the Kohinoor but inherited it later after Shah Jahan.
  • Murad was Shah Jahan’s son but not associated with the diamond.
  • Abul Hasan Qutb Shah, the last ruler of Golconda, lost control of the mines to the Mughals, but did not gift the diamond.

question: Who among the following historians called the reign of Shahjahan as the 'Golden Age' of the Mughal period?
option_4: All the three of the above
solution:
• The reign of Shah Jahan (1628–1658 CE) is often referred to as the 'Golden Age of the Mughal Empire' due to its peak in architecture, art, and cultural grandeur.
  • Multiple historians have described Shah Jahan’s rule with this title or sentiment.
  • Khafi Khan, a contemporary chronicler, praised Shah Jahan’s administration, prosperity, and justice.
  • Rai Bharmal, an Indian historian, also emphasized the flourishing of arts and literature under Shah Jahan.
  • Francois Bernier, a French traveler and historian who visited India during this period, admired the splendor and architectural marvels like the Taj Mahal and Red Fort.
  • Hence, all three—Khafi Khan, Rai Bharmal, and Bernier—acknowledged Shah Jahan’s reign as a golden period in Mughal history.

Additional Information:

  • Major monuments of this era include Taj Mahal, Red Fort, Jama Masjid, and Shalimar Gardens.
  • The empire was economically prosperous, and administrative systems were stable during his rule.

question: Who is known as 'Little Akbar’?
solution:
• Dara Shikoh was the eldest son of Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan.
  • He was a liberal and intellectual prince who tried to bridge Hindu-Muslim religious philosophies, especially by translating Upanishads and Bhagavad Gita into Persian.
  • Due to his syncretic views, tolerance, and efforts toward religious harmony, he was nicknamed ‘Little Akbar’, drawing a comparison with Emperor Akbar, who was famous for his religious tolerance and secularism.
  • His ideas were in contrast to his brother Aurangzeb, who later defeated him and took the throne.

Additional Information:

  • Dara Shikoh authored 'Majma-ul-Bahrain' (The Mingling of Two Oceans), which highlighted the similarities between Sufism and Vedanta.
  • He was declared the Crown Prince but lost the war of succession to Aurangzeb.
  • He was executed in 1659 on Aurangzeb’s orders.

question:
The first Muslim to study Hindu scriptures was–

UPPSC (Mains), 2003
solution:
• Dara Shikoh was the first Muslim prince who showed deep interest in Hindu scriptures.
  • He studied and translated several Hindu philosophical texts like the Upanishads, Bhagavad Gita, and Yoga Vasistha into Persian.
  • His goal was to find a common spiritual ground between Islamic Sufism and Hindu Vedanta philosophy.
  • He titled the Persian translation of the Upanishads as “Sirr-e-Akbar” (The Great Secret).

Additional Information:

  • Dara Shikoh's comparative work ‘Majma-ul-Bahrain’ (The Mingling of Two Oceans) highlighted the similarities between Islam and Hinduism.
  • He believed the Upanishads contained the hidden wisdom mentioned in the Quran.
  • His efforts were unique and unprecedented among Muslim scholars of his time.

question:
The Battle of Dharmat was fought between which of the following?

IAS, 2003
option_2: Ahmad Shah Durrani and Marathas
option_3: Aurangzeb and Dara Shikoh
option_4: Muhammad Ghori and Jaichand
solution:
• The Battle of Dharmat was fought on 15 April 1658 between Aurangzeb and his elder brother Dara Shikoh.
  • This battle was part of the Mughal war of succession after Emperor Shah Jahan fell seriously ill.
  • The battle took place near Ujjain in Madhya Pradesh.
  • Dara Shikoh’s forces were led by Raja Jaswant Singh of Marwar, while Aurangzeb allied with his brother Murad Baksh.

Additional Information:

  • Dara’s forces were defeated due to poor planning and lack of unity among commanders.
  • This battle gave a decisive edge to Aurangzeb, helping him move towards the Mughal throne.
  • Later, Aurangzeb also defeated Dara at the Battle of Samugarh, leading to Dara’s downfall and execution.

question:
The Mughal prince who had taken shelter in Srinagar Garhwal

Uttarakhand PCS (Pre), 2004
solution:
• Sulaiman Shikoh was the son of Dara Shikoh, the eldest son of Emperor Shah Jahan.
  • After Dara Shikoh was defeated by Aurangzeb during the Mughal war of succession, Sulaiman Shikoh sought refuge in the Garhwal region, specifically Srinagar (in present-day Uttarakhand).
  • He was sheltered by the Garhwal king Prithvi Pat Shah for some time.
  • Later, Aurangzeb forced the king to hand over Sulaiman Shikoh, after which he was imprisoned and poisoned to death in 1662.

Additional Information:

  • Sulaiman was known for his bravery and was once considered a potential successor to Dara Shikoh.
  • His capture and execution were part of Aurangzeb’s systematic elimination of rivals to secure the throne.

question:
Which of the following Mughal Emperors was coronated twice?

UPPSC (Mains), 2006, UPPSC (Mains), 2009
solution:
• Aurangzeb was coronated (crowned) twice as the Mughal Emperor.
  • His first coronation took place in 1658 at Delhi, shortly after defeating his brothers in the war of succession.
  • However, due to unfavorable astrological timing, a second coronation was held in July 1659 with full imperial rituals.
  • The two coronations emphasized his legitimacy and divine sanction as emperor.

Additional Information:

  • Aurangzeb assumed the title “Alamgir”, meaning Conqueror of the World.
  • His reign lasted from 1658 to 1707, the longest of any Mughal emperor.
  • His rule marked the expansion of the Mughal Empire to its greatest territorial extent but also sowed seeds of future decline due to religious orthodoxy and prolonged wars.

question:
With which Mughal general did Shivaji sign the Treaty of Purandar (1665 A.D.) during the reign of Aurangzeb?

UPPSC (Mains), 2008, 09, UPPSC (Pre), 2011, UPUDA/LDA (SPL) (Pre), 2010
solution:
• The Treaty of Purandar was signed in 1665 A.D. between Shivaji Maharaj and the Mughal Empire during the reign of Aurangzeb.
  • The treaty was signed with Mirza Raja Jai Singh, a senior Mughal general and trusted commander of Aurangzeb.
  • Jai Singh had launched a military campaign against Shivaji and forced him into negotiations after besieging Purandar Fort.
  • Under the terms of the treaty, Shivaji ceded 23 forts to the Mughals and agreed to send his son Sambhaji to the Mughal court.

Additional Information:

  • The treaty was a strategic move by Shivaji to preserve his core territory and regroup.
  • Jai Singh assured personal safety for Shivaji, which later led him to visit the Mughal court, where he was arrested but eventually escaped from Agra.

question:
Which Mughal emperor was called 'Zinda Peer’?

Jharkhand PCS (Pre), 2003
solution:
• The title 'Zinda Peer', meaning 'Living Saint', was given to Mughal Emperor Aurangzeb.
  • He earned this title due to his strict Islamic lifestyle, personal piety, and devotion to religion.
  • Aurangzeb was known for observing daily prayers, copying the Quran by hand, and leading a simple, austere life despite being an emperor.
  • Unlike earlier Mughal rulers, he avoided luxury, banned music in the court, and enforced Islamic laws (Sharia) in governance.

Additional Information:

  • Aurangzeb also abolished many practices he deemed un-Islamic, including the pilgrimage tax and celebration of certain festivals.
  • His religious orthodoxy and intolerance toward other faiths (particularly Hindu practices) contributed to discontent and rebellion in various parts of the empire.
  • His reign, while territorially vast, saw the beginning of Mughal decline due to overextension and unrest.

question:
The two states which Aurangzeb conquered in the south were–

UPPSC (Pre), 2004, UP Lower Sub (Pre), 2004
solution:
• The two major Deccan Sultanates that Aurangzeb conquered in the south were Bijapur and Golconda.
  • Bijapur was annexed by the Mughals in 1686 after a prolonged siege.
  • Golconda fell in 1687, following the betrayal of its commander and sustained military campaign by Aurangzeb.
  • These conquests marked the end of independent Deccan Sultanates and extended the Mughal Empire to its maximum territorial limits.

Additional Information:

  • The annexation of Bijapur and Golconda was part of Aurangzeb’s Deccan policy aimed at bringing the entire peninsula under Mughal control.
  • However, continuous warfare in the south drained the empire’s resources and weakened central control, leading to the eventual decline of the Mughal Empire.

question:
'Jizya' was re-imposed during whose reign?

UPPSC (Pre), 2002
solution:
• Jizya was a tax imposed on non-Muslims (Dhimmis) in an Islamic state in exchange for protection and exemption from military service.
  • It was abolished by Akbar in the 16th century as part of his secular and inclusive policies.
  • However, it was re-imposed by Aurangzeb in 1679, reflecting his orthodox Islamic ideology.
  • The decision faced widespread resistance, especially from Hindus and Rajputs, and became one of the reasons for discontent and uprisings during his reign.

Additional Information:

  • The re-imposition of Jizya is seen as part of Aurangzeb’s move toward religious conservatism, contrasting sharply with the liberal policies of his predecessors.
  • It contributed to alienating non-Muslim subjects and undermining the internal unity of the Mughal Empire.

question:
Which tomb is called the 'Second Taj Mahal’?

UPPSC (Pre), 2000, UPPSC (Mains), 2013
solution:
• The Tomb of Sabz Burj, also known as the Tomb of Sabia-ud-Daurani, is often referred to as the ‘Second Taj Mahal’ due to its architectural similarity and emotional background.
  • It was built in Aurangabad (Maharashtra) by Emperor Aurangzeb in memory of his wife Rabia-ud-Daurani (also known as Dilras Banu Begum).
  • The tomb is officially named Bibi Ka Maqbara.
  • It resembles the Taj Mahal, which was built by Shah Jahan for his wife Mumtaz Mahal.

Additional Information:

  • Bibi Ka Maqbara was constructed between 1651 and 1661 A.D.
  • It was commissioned by Aurangzeb’s son Azam Shah, not Aurangzeb himself.
  • Though similar in design, it is smaller in scale and less ornate than the Taj Mahal.
  • It stands as a symbol of Mughal architecture’s continuity into the later Mughal era.

question:
To whom did Aurangzeb confer the title of 'Sahibat-uz-Zamani’?

UPPSC (Pre), 2014
solution:
• The title ‘Sahibat-uz-Zamani’, meaning ‘Mistress of the Age’, was conferred by Aurangzeb upon his sister Jahanara Begum.
  • Jahanara was the eldest daughter of Emperor Shah Jahan and was a highly influential figure in the Mughal court even after her father's imprisonment.
  • Despite supporting Dara Shikoh during the war of succession, Aurangzeb respected her wisdom, piety, and political influence, and later granted her this prestigious title.
  • She continued to have prominent status during Aurangzeb’s reign.

Additional Information:

  • Jahanara was known for her literary works, charity, and her deep Sufi devotion.
  • She authored works like “Munis-ul-Arwah” and was a disciple of the Qadiri Sufi order.
  • Her tomb is in Delhi, near the shrine of Hazrat Nizamuddin Auliya, reflecting her spiritual leanings.

question:
Which Mughal emperor appointed the largest number of Hindu officers?

UPPSC (Pre), 1998, UP Lower Sub. (Pre), 2004
solution:
• Though Aurangzeb is often associated with religious orthodoxy, **he appointed the largest number of Hindu officers in the Mughal administration.
  • This was mainly because the empire had expanded significantly during his reign, necessitating a larger and more diverse bureaucracy.
  • Many Hindus, especially Rajputs, were given administrative and military positions, including high-ranking posts.
  • Notably, more than 30% of his nobility were of Hindu origin, a higher percentage than under Akbar.

Additional Information:

  • This contradicts the popular image of Aurangzeb as entirely anti-Hindu, indicating a pragmatic approach to governance.
  • Akbar is credited for starting the practice of inclusive appointments, but under Aurangzeb, the actual number of Hindu officials was the highest due to the empire’s size and administrative needs.
  • Prominent Hindu nobles like Raja Jai Singh and Raja Jaswant Singh served under Aurangzeb.

question:
The meaning of 'Jihad' launched by Aurangzeb was–

BPSC (Pre), 1999
solution:
• During Aurangzeb’s reign, ‘Jihad’ was used in the context of promoting and protecting Islamic governance.
  • The term ‘Dar-ul-Islam’ refers to a territory under Islamic rule, where Islamic laws (Sharia) are implemented.
  • Aurangzeb’s Jihad aimed at expanding the Dar-ul-Islam by bringing non-Islamic territories under Muslim rule and implementing Islamic laws.
  • His religious policies were focused on converting India from Dar-ul-Harb (land of war) to Dar-ul-Islam (land of Islam).

Additional Information:

  • Aurangzeb re-imposed Jizya, banned music, and enforced Sharia law.
  • His campaigns in the Deccan and against Rajput and Maratha rulers were often justified as religiously sanctioned efforts to spread Islamic governance.
  • While 'Jihad' literally means struggle or effort in the path of God, Aurangzeb used it primarily in the political-religious context of territorial expansion.

question:
Assertion (A): Aurangzeb succeeded Shah Jahan on the Mughal throne.

Reason (R): The rule of succession of the eldest son was followed.

Choose the correct answer from the following–

UPPSC (Pre), 1994
option_1: Both (A) and (R) are true, and (R) is the correct explanation of (A)
option_2: Both (A) and (R) are true, but (R) is not the correct explanation of (A)
option_3: (A) is true, (R) is false
option_4: (A) is false, (R) is true
solution:
• Assertion (A) is true: Aurangzeb did succeed Shah Jahan and became the Mughal emperor in 1658, following a bitter war of succession.
  • Reason (R) is false: The Mughal Empire did not follow a fixed rule of succession such as primogeniture (eldest son succeeding).
  • Instead, succession was determined by power struggles among the emperor’s sons.
  • Aurangzeb was not the eldest son; Dara Shikoh was the eldest and was also Shah Jahan’s favorite.
  • Aurangzeb defeated all his brothers (Dara, Murad, and Shuja) to seize the throne by force, not by any hereditary rule.

Correct Answer:(c) (A) is true, (R) is false

question:
Which son of Aurangzeb rebelled and weakened his father's position against the Rajputs?

UPPSC (Mains), 2007
solution:
• Prince Akbar, the fourth son of Aurangzeb, rebelled against his father in 1681.
  • He joined hands with the Rajput ruler Maharana Raj Singh of Mewar, who was resisting Mughal domination.
  • This alliance with the Rajputs created a serious challenge to Aurangzeb’s authority in the Deccan and Rajasthan regions.
  • The rebellion weakened Mughal control over Rajput territories and diverted military resources, damaging Aurangzeb's position.

Additional Information:

  • After the failed rebellion, Prince Akbar fled to Persia (Iran) and never returned to India.
  • His defection marked a significant moment of internal dissent in Aurangzeb’s reign, revealing the growing cracks within the Mughal Empire.
  • The rebellion also highlighted the strained relations between the Mughals and the Rajputs during this period.

question:
During the reign of which Mughal ruler was 'Biwi Ka Makbara' built?

RAS/RTS (Pre), 1999
solution:
• The Bibi Ka Maqbara (meaning Tomb of the Lady) was built during the reign of Aurangzeb in Aurangabad, Maharashtra.
  • It was constructed in memory of Dilras Banu Begum, Aurangzeb’s wife, who was also known by the title Rabia-ud-Daurani.
  • The tomb was commissioned by their son, Prince Azam Shah, around 1651–1661 A.D. during Aurangzeb’s rule.
  • The structure closely resembles the Taj Mahal and is often called the “Taj of the Deccan” or “Second Taj Mahal”.

Additional Information:

  • Unlike Shah Jahan who built the Taj Mahal with immense expenditure, Aurangzeb was more austere, and Bibi Ka Maqbara was built at a much lower cost.
  • The tomb reflects Mughal architectural style, though on a simpler and smaller scale compared to the Taj Mahal.

question:
Who among the following was the daughter of Emperor Aurangzeb?

UPPSC (Mains), 2005
solution:
• Gauhar Ara Begum was the daughter of Mughal Emperor Aurangzeb and his wife Dilras Banu Begum.
  • She was known for her modesty, religious devotion, and remained unmarried throughout her life.
  • She lived during a time of intense political and military activity under Aurangzeb and was close to her father.

Clarification of Options:

  • (a) Jahanara – Daughter of Shah Jahan, not Aurangzeb.
  • (b) Roshan Ara – Also daughter of Shah Jahan, and sister of Aurangzeb.
  • (c) Gauhar Ara – Correct answer, daughter of Aurangzeb.
  • (d) Mehrunnisa – This was the original name of Nur Jahan, wife of Jahangir, not Aurangzeb’s daughter.

Additional Information:

  • Gauhar Ara was the youngest child of Aurangzeb.
  • She died in 1730 A.D., many years after Aurangzeb’s death in 1707.

question:
To whose reign is Saint Ramdas associated?

UPPSC (Mains), 2009
solution:
• Saint Ramdas (1608–1681), also known as Samarth Ramdas, was a renowned Marathi saint, philosopher, and spiritual leader.
  • He is most closely associated with the reign of Aurangzeb.
  • Saint Ramdas was the spiritual guru of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj, the Maratha king who resisted Mughal rule under Aurangzeb.
  • His teachings emphasized discipline, devotion to Lord Rama, and service to the nation (Swarajya).

Additional Information:

  • Ramdas composed the famous “Dasbodh” and “Manache Shlok”, guiding moral and spiritual conduct.
  • He encouraged Shivaji to establish Hindavi Swarajya and provided moral-spiritual guidance during a politically turbulent period.
  • His life and work directly paralleled the time when Aurangzeb was actively expanding the Mughal Empire, particularly in the Deccan.

question:
Moti Masjid in Red Fort of Delhi was built by–

UPPSC (Pre), 2001,

UPUDA/LDA (Pre), 2002
solution:
• The Moti Masjid (Pearl Mosque) inside the Red Fort of Delhi was built by Mughal Emperor Aurangzeb in 1659 A.D.
  • It is a small but elegant white marble mosque, meant for private worship by the royal family.
  • The mosque is located near the Diwan-i-Khas within the Red Fort complex.

Additional Information:

  • The name “Moti Masjid” (Pearl Mosque) comes from its pure white marble structure, giving it a shimmering pearl-like appearance.
  • It should not be confused with another Moti Masjid built by Shah Jahan in Agra Fort — that one was constructed earlier.
  • Aurangzeb’s version in Delhi was modest in size but reflected his personal religious devotion and architectural simplicity.

question:
Who among the following was a Jahangiri painter? Choose the correct answer from the code given below:

UPPSC (Pre), 2012

Abdussamad

2. Abul Hasan

3. Akarija

4. Mir Sayyed Ali

Codes:
solution:
• Abul Hasan and Akarija were prominent painters in the court of Emperor Jahangir, known for his deep interest in miniature paintings and portrait art.
  • Jahangir greatly patronized the Mughal school of painting, and under his reign, portraiture and naturalistic themes reached their peak.
  • Abul Hasan earned the title “Nadir-uz-Zaman” (Wonder of the Age) from Jahangir due to his artistic brilliance.
  • Akarija was another painter associated with Jahangir’s court, contributing to various illustrated manuscripts and royal commissions.

Why Others Are Incorrect:

  • Abdussamad and Mir Sayyed Ali were painters of the early Mughal period, especially under Humayun and Akbar, not Jahangir.
  • They were part of the team brought from Persia to India by Humayun.

Correct Code: (b) 2 and 3

question:
'Dastan-e-Amir Hamza' was illustrated by whom?

46th BPSC (Pre), 2004
solution:
• 'Dastan-e-Amir Hamza' is a famous Persian epic that narrates the adventures of Amir Hamza, the uncle of Prophet Muhammad.
  • During the Mughal period, Emperor Akbar commissioned an illustrated manuscript of this tale.
  • The illustrations were part of an enormous project involving around 1,400 paintings, making it one of the most ambitious illustrated manuscripts ever produced.
  • Among the key artists of Akbar’s court, Abdussamad was one of the chief painters who contributed to this monumental task.
  • Abdussamad, along with Mir Sayyed Ali, was invited from Persia by Emperor Humayun and later served Akbar. However, Abdussamad is primarily credited for directing the project of illustrating the Dastan-e-Amir Hamza.

Additional Information:

  • The illustrated Hamzanama was started around 1557 and took more than a decade to complete.
  • The paintings are noted for their large size and bold, vibrant compositions.
  • This work laid the foundation for the Mughal school of painting, blending Persian and Indian artistic traditions.

question:
Which one of the following pairs is correctly matched?

UPPSC (Mains), 2009
solution:
• (a) Babur – Tuzuk-e-Baburi: ✔️Correctly matched

    Babur wrote his memoirs in Turki (Chagatai Turkish), known as the Baburnama or Tuzuk-e-Baburi. It provides a detailed account of his life, campaigns, and observations.

  • (b) Humayun – Humayun-nama: ❌Incorrect

    The Humayun-nama was not written by Humayun, but by his sister Gulbadan Begum, describing the life of Humayun and the Mughal court.

  • (c) Sher Shah – Tarikh-e-Sher Shahi: ❌Incorrect

    This was not authored by Sher Shah himself. It was written by Abbas Sarwani, a historian during the reign of Akbar, and it documents Sher Shah’s administration.

  • (d) Akbar – Tabaqat-e-Akbari: ❌Incorrect

    Tabaqat-e-Akbari was written by Nizamuddin Ahmad, a historian in Akbar’s court. It’s not authored by Akbar.

Hence, the correct answer is: (a) Babur – Tuzuk-e-Baburi

question:
Which of the following statements is/are true regarding Mughal architecture?

The chief architect of the Taj Mahal was Ustad Ahmad Lahori.

2. Delhi's Jama Masjid is constructed of red sandstone.

3. Jahangir showed interest in the construction of gardens and flowerbeds.

Codes:
solution:
• Statement 1: The chief architect of the Taj Mahal was Ustad Ahmad Lahori

    ✔️True — Ustad Ahmad Lahori is widely believed to be the chief architect behind the Taj Mahal, commissioned by Shah Jahan.

  • Statement 2: Delhi's Jama Masjid is constructed of red sandstone

    ✔️True — The Jama Masjid in Delhi, also built by Shah Jahan, was constructed using red sandstone and white marble.

  • Statement 3: Jahangir showed interest in the construction of gardens and flowerbeds

    ✔️True — Jahangir was known for his love of nature, and he promoted the development of Mughal gardens, with special attention to landscaping and floral aesthetics.

All three statements are correct.

question:
Who among the following women wrote historical accounts during the Mughal period?

IAS, 1994, UPPSC (Pre), 1998
solution:
• Gulbadan Begum was the daughter of Babur and sister of Humayun.
  • She authored the historical work "Humayun-nama", which provides a firsthand account of Humayun’s life and also valuable insights into the Mughal court and royal women.
  • It is considered one of the very few historical accounts written by a woman during the Mughal era.
  • This work is written in Persian and holds significance as an insider’s narrative from the Mughal harem.

The other options, although prominent Mughal women, did not write historical accounts:

  • Noor Jahan Begum: Wife of Jahangir, powerful and politically active, but did not author any historical texts.
  • Jahanara Begum: Daughter of Shah Jahan, wrote biographies (like Risala-i-Sahibiyah) but more spiritual than historical.
  • Zebunnisa Begum: Daughter of Aurangzeb, known for poetry under the pen name Makhfi, but not historical writings.

question:
Aurangzeb was proficient in playing which of the following musical instruments?

UPPSC (Mains), 2007. UPPSC (Pre), 2010
option_4: None of the above
solution:
• Aurangzeb, despite his strict Islamic policies, was personally trained in classical music during his youth.
  • He was proficient in playing the Veena (also called Rudra Veena), a traditional Indian string instrument.
  • Historical texts and Mughal court records confirm that Aurangzeb received musical training in his early years.
  • However, after becoming emperor, he banned music in his court due to religious reasons, but he never denied his own musical knowledge.
  • Other options like Sitar and Pakhavaj are incorrect, as there is no record of his association with these instruments.

Additional Information:

  • The Veena is a plucked string instrument used in Indian classical music.
  • Aurangzeb ordered the destruction of musical instruments from his court, yet a Veena was found among his personal belongings after his death.
  • He once remarked: "Music is the soul of the universe," showing his inner appreciation despite public bans.

question:
Tansen's tomb during Akbar's time is located in-

MPPSC (Pre), 1991, 2010, UPPSC (Pre), 1999
solution:
• Tansen, one of the navratnas (nine jewels) in Akbar's court, was a legendary classical musician.
  • He originally belonged to Gwalior, which was a major center of music and culture.
  • After his death, his tomb was built in Gwalior, near the tomb of his music teacher Muhammad Ghaus.
  • The site is now a place of cultural pilgrimage, especially during the Tansen Samaroh, a national music festival.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Gwalior.

Additional Information:

  • Tansen is credited with creating several ragas and developing the Hindustani classical music tradition.
  • His tomb in Gwalior is an example of Mughal architectural influence blended with local elements.
  • The annual Tansen Music Festival held here attracts classical musicians from all over India.

question:
Who composed 'Humayunnama’?

UPPSC (Mains), 2002, UPPSC (Pre), 2004, UKPSC (Pre), 2010
solution:
• The 'Humayunnama' is a historical biography of Mughal emperor Humayun.
  • It was written by Gulbadan Begum, the daughter of Babur and sister of Humayun.
  • She was commissioned by Akbar to write an account of Humayun’s life and early Mughal rule.
  • The work is written in Persian and offers a first-hand female perspective, rare for that time.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Gulbadan Begum.

Additional Information:

  • 'Humayunnama' is valued for its personal tone, vivid narration, and family insights.
  • Gulbadan Begum was well-educated and had close access to the royal household, making her work a vital source for Mughal history.
  • This work complements other Mughal chronicles like Baburnama and Akbarnama.

question:
The book 'Anwar-e-Suhayli' is the translation of which of the following?

UPPSC (Pre), 1999
solution:
• The book 'Anwar-e-Suhayli' is a Persian translation of the ancient Indian collection of animal fables known as the Panchatantra.
  • It was translated by Husain Va'iz Kashifi, a Persian scholar during the Timurid period.
  • The name 'Anwar-e-Suhayli' means "The Lights of Canopus" (Canopus being a bright star), indicating its moral and illuminating stories.
  • This version became popular in the Islamic world and influenced later translations into Turkish and European languages.
  • Thus, the correct answer is Panchtantra.

Additional Information:

  • The Panchatantra was originally written in Sanskrit by Vishnu Sharma.
  • It contains animal-based fables meant to teach political science and moral lessons to young princes.
  • 'Anwar-e-Suhayli' was later adopted by the Mughals and became part of their literary culture.

question:
The original name of Tansen was-

MPPSC (Pre), 2013
solution:
• The original name of Tansen, one of the greatest musicians in Indian history and a navratna in Akbar's court, was Ramtanu Pandey.
  • He was born in a Hindu family in Gwalior and later became a disciple of the Sufi saint Muhammad Ghaus.
  • Under the patronage of Raja Ramchandra of Rewa, he was trained and gained fame before joining Akbar’s court.
  • Akbar honored him with the title “Tansen”, meaning a gifted musician.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Ramtanu Pandey.

Additional Information:

  • Tansen is credited with composing several ragas, and legend says he could light lamps by singing Raga Deepak and bring rain with Raga Megh Malhar.
  • He played a major role in shaping the Hindustani classical music tradition.
  • Tansen's legacy continues through the Tansen Samaroh, an annual music festival held in Gwalior.

question:
In 1773 A.D., the author of the book 'Zij Muhammad Shahi' which is related to the knowledge of constellations is-

RAS/RTS (Pre), 2007
option_1: Jaswant Singh of Jodhpur
option_2: Raja Bharmal of Amer
option_3: Sawai Jai Singh of Jaipur
option_4: Maharana Amar Singh of Udaipur
solution:
• The book 'Zij Muhammad Shahi' is a famous astronomical text authored by Sawai Jai Singh of Jaipur.
  • It was written around 1773 A.D., and the title was given in honor of Mughal emperor Muhammad Shah.
  • This work focuses on astronomy, especially on celestial calculations and star positions (Zij refers to astronomical tables).
  • Sawai Jai Singh was a renowned scholar and astronomer who built five observatories (Jantar Mantars) in India, including the famous one in Jaipur.
  • Thus, the correct answer is Sawai Jai Singh of Jaipur.

Additional Information:

  • Jai Singh’s interest in astronomy led him to study ancient Hindu, Islamic, and European texts.
  • He revised existing astronomical tables using more precise instruments of his time.
  • 'Zij Muhammad Shahi' is considered a significant contribution to Indian astronomical literature.

question: Which of the following Mughal rulers introduced the coin called 'Aana’?
solution:
• The coin called ‘Aana’ (also spelled Anna) was introduced during the reign of Shahjahan, the 5th Mughal emperor.
  • It was a fractional denomination of the Rupee, where 1 Rupee = 16 Aanas.
  • Shahjahan’s period witnessed several monetary reforms and refinements in the Mughal coinage system, including standardization of weights and introduction of fractional coins.
  • The ‘Aana’ coin made trade easier, especially for small transactions and daily commerce.
  • Thus, the correct answer is Shahjahan.

Additional Information:

  • Mughal coins were known for their purity and fine calligraphy.
  • The Rupee, as a currency, was first introduced by Sher Shah Suri, but it was under the Mughals that its denominations like Aana, Paisa, and Dam became well-structured.
  • The Aana system remained in use even during British India, until the decimal system replaced it in 1957.

question:
Who among the following was the head of the army during the Mughal period?

UPPSC (Pre), 1992
solution:
• During the Mughal period, the Mir Bakshi was the head of the army.
  • Appointed directly by the emperor, the Mir Bakshi was responsible for:
    • Recruitment of soldiers
    • Maintenance of military records
    • Distribution of salaries and ranks (Mansabs)
    • Inspection of army troops
  • Though the emperor was the supreme commander, Mir Bakshi acted as the executive military officer.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Mir Bakshi.

Additional Information:

  • The Wazir was the head of revenue and administration, not the military.
  • Shahna-e-Peel dealt with the management of elephants.
  • Savahenigar was responsible for keeping records of horses.
  • The Mansabdari system, which Mir Bakshi managed, classified nobles according to their military rank and position.

question:
In the Mughal administration the Muhtasib was-

47th BPSC (Pre), 2005
option_2: Chief of Foreign Department
option_4: Officer of Correspondence Department
solution:
• In the Mughal administration, the Muhtasib was a Public Conduct Officer.
  • His primary duty was to ensure moral behavior and enforce Islamic laws in public life.
  • Responsibilities included:
    • Monitoring markets for fair trade practices
    • Preventing gambling, drinking, and immoral acts
    • Ensuring proper Friday prayers and public discipline
  • The Muhtasib acted like a civic inspector to uphold religious and social norms.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Public Conduct Officer.

Additional Information:

  • The post of Muhtasib had existed in Islamic governance traditions even before the Mughals.
  • He worked independently from other departments like army (Mir Bakshi) or revenue (Diwan).
  • The Muhtasib had no judicial authority, but could report offenses to the Qazi.

question:
By what name was the district known during the Mughal administration?

UKPSC (Pre), 2004
solution:
• During the Mughal administration, the empire was divided into several levels of territorial units.
  • The largest unit was called a Suba (province), governed by a Subedar.
  • Each Suba was further divided into Sarkars, which were equivalent to districts.
  • So, the Sarkar was the administrative unit corresponding to a modern-day district.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Sarkar.

Additional Information:

  • A Sarkar was further subdivided into Parganas, and parganas into villages.
  • The key officers at Sarkar level included Faujdar (military officer) and Amil (revenue officer).
  • This administrative structure was part of Akbar’s reforms introduced by Raja Todar Mal under the Ain-i-Akbari.

question:
Who took power after the death of Aurangzeb in 1707 AD?

UPPSC (Mains), 2012
solution:
• After the death of Aurangzeb in 1707 AD, a war of succession broke out among his sons.
  • His eldest son Muazzam emerged victorious and ascended the throne as Bahadur Shah I.
  • Bahadur Shah I ruled from 1707 to 1712, and he is also known as Shah Alam I.
  • His reign marked the beginning of the decline of centralized Mughal power, though he tried to maintain authority over rebellious nobles and regional powers.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Bahadur Shah I.

Additional Information:

  • Bahadur Shah I tried to reconcile with Rajputs, Marathas, and Sikhs, but could not assert firm control.
  • After his death, a rapid decline began with short-reigning and weak successors like Jahandar Shah and Farrukhsiyar.
  • His coronation ended a 3-month war of succession among his brothers, including Azam Shah and Kam Baksh.

question: The Mughal emperor who was known by the nickname 'Shahe Bekhabar’?
solution:
• The nickname 'Shahe Bekhabar' translates to "The Unaware King" or "Ignorant Emperor".
  • It was used for Bahadur Shah I, who ruled from 1707 to 1712 AD, succeeding Aurangzeb.
  • Though he tried to maintain control over a disintegrating empire, his lack of strong action and passive governance earned him this unflattering title.
  • His failure to decisively handle regional uprisings and power struggles led historians and critics to call him 'Shahe Bekhabar'.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Bahadur Shah I.

Additional Information:

  • During his reign, Sikh, Maratha, and Rajput assertions increased, but he couldn't suppress them effectively.
  • Bahadur Shah I adopted a policy of conciliation, which many perceived as weakness.
  • His reign marked the beginning of the rapid decline of the Mughal Empire after Aurangzeb.

question: In honour of which Sikh Guru did the Mughal Emperor Bahadur Shah I (1707–1712 AD) confer high mansabs?
solution:
• The Mughal emperor Bahadur Shah I (1707–1712 AD) conferred high mansabs (ranks) in honor of Guru Gobind Singh, the 10th Sikh Guru.
  • After the death of Aurangzeb, Bahadur Shah I sought to reconcile with the Sikhs and gain their support.
  • Guru Gobind Singh met Bahadur Shah I in 1707 at Agra and Nanded, and supported his claim to the throne during the war of succession.
  • As a gesture of goodwill, Bahadur Shah I bestowed high ranks and honors on the Guru and his associates.
  • Thus, the correct answer is Guru Gobind Singh.

Additional Information:

  • Though the relations began with diplomacy, they soured later due to the murder of Guru Gobind Singh in 1708.
  • After the Guru's death, Banda Bahadur, his disciple, launched armed resistance against the Mughals.
  • Guru Gobind Singh played a pivotal role in organizing Sikhs militarily, founding the Khalsa in 1699.

question: Which Mughal emperor was called a 'lustful fool’?
solution:
• The Mughal emperor Jahandar Shah, who ruled for a brief period from 1712 to 1713, was often referred to by historians as a “lustful fool”.
  • He gained a reputation for indulging in pleasure, luxury, and immoral activities, neglecting administration and governance.
  • Jahandar Shah’s rule was heavily influenced by his mistress and later consort Lal Kunwar, a dancing girl whom he elevated to royal status.
  • Due to his indulgent lifestyle and poor leadership, both contemporaries and later chroniclers described him with this derogatory label.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Jahandar Shah.

Additional Information:

  • Jahandar Shah came to power after a war of succession following the death of Bahadur Shah I.
  • He was defeated and deposed by his nephew Farrukhsiyar with the help of the powerful Sayyid brothers.
  • His brief and chaotic reign is remembered more for court scandals and extravagance than for any administrative achievement.

question: Which Mughal emperor gave the title of 'Raja' to Ram Mohan Roy?
solution:
• The title of 'Raja' was conferred upon Raja Ram Mohan Roy by Mughal emperor Akbar II.
  • Akbar II ruled from 1806 to 1837, a time when the Mughal Empire had lost political power but retained symbolic authority.
  • Impressed by Ram Mohan Roy's intellect and diplomatic skills, Akbar II sent him to England in 1831 as his representative (ambassador) to plead for the Mughal pension.
  • As a mark of honor and trust, Akbar II gave him the title "Raja" before his journey.
  • Thus, the correct answer is Akbar II.

Additional Information:

  • Raja Ram Mohan Roy is regarded as the Father of the Indian Renaissance and the founder of the Brahmo Samaj.
  • He campaigned for social reforms, especially against Sati, child marriage, and caste discrimination.
  • His mission to England was also to represent Indian interests before the British crown.

question: Which Mughal emperor was murdered by the Syed Bandhu due to a conspiracy against them?
solution:
• The Mughal emperor Farrukhsiyar (ruled 1713–1719 AD) was murdered by the Syed Brothers due to a conspiracy against them.
  • The Syed Bandhu (Syed Brothers – Syed Abdullah Khan and Syed Hussain Ali Khan) were powerful kingmakers who helped Farrukhsiyar ascend the throne.
  • Over time, Farrukhsiyar grew suspicious of their influence and attempted to weaken or remove them.
  • In retaliation, the Syed Brothers deposed and imprisoned him, and later got him murdered in 1719.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Farrukhsiyar.

Additional Information:

  • Farrukhsiyar’s reign is often remembered for the dominance of the Syed Brothers, who effectively controlled the empire.
  • This period is known as the “Era of Sayyid Brothers” or “Kingmakers of the Mughal Empire.”
  • His downfall marked the beginning of a puppet ruler phase, where emperors were controlled by powerful nobles.

question: The Syed Bandhu were-
option_1: Amirs of Persia and Khurasan
option_2: Foreign Muslim Amirs of Hindustani origin
option_3: Amirs of Central Asian origin
option_4: Soldiers of the Mughal court
solution:
• The Syed Bandhu or Syed Brothers, namely Syed Abdullah Khan and Syed Hussain Ali Khan, were foreign Muslim amirs of Hindustani origin.
  • They claimed descent from the Prophet Muhammad, hence the title "Syed".
  • Though they were Indian-born (Hindustani origin), they were considered part of the foreign Muslim elite due to their Arab lineage and connections within the imperial Mughal court.
  • They rose to power during the reign of Bahadur Shah I and Farrukhsiyar, and became the de facto rulers of the empire for several years.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Foreign Muslim Amirs of Hindustani origin.

Additional Information:

  • The Syed Brothers played a key role in installing and deposing Mughal emperors, earning the nickname “Kingmakers.”
  • They were opposed by rival factions like the Turani and Irani nobles, leading to court conspiracies and eventual downfall.
  • Their era marks the beginning of nobility-dominated Mughal rule, weakening the emperor’s direct control.

question: During the tenure of which Mughal emperor, was the Jaziya tax imposed by Aurangzeb completely abolished?
solution:
• The Jaziya tax was a religious tax imposed by Aurangzeb on non-Muslims in 1679.
  • It was deeply unpopular and symbolized religious intolerance during his reign.
  • After Aurangzeb’s death, many of his orthodox policies were reversed by subsequent rulers.
  • The complete abolition of Jaziya took place during the reign of Farrukhsiyar (1713–1719 AD).
  • Farrukhsiyar, under the influence of more liberal nobles and changing political circumstances, formally abolished the Jaziya to gain favor with Hindu subjects.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Farrukhsiyar.

Additional Information:

  • The Jaziya had been previously abolished by Akbar in the 16th century and reimposed by Aurangzeb.
  • Its re-imposition had led to resentment among non-Muslims, particularly Hindus and Rajputs.
  • Abolition under Farrukhsiyar was part of a broader move toward pragmatic and inclusive governance to stabilize a declining empire.

question:
Who among the following foreign travellers visited India during the reign of Jahangir?

UPPSC (Pre), 2017
solution:
• Francisco Pelsaert, a Dutch traveler and official of the Dutch East India Company, visited India during the reign of Mughal Emperor Jahangir (1605–1627).
  • He arrived in India in the 1620s, just before Jahangir’s death, and later recorded his observations in a famous work titled "Remonstrantie".
  • His account provides detailed insights into the economic conditions, administration, and society under the Mughal Empire.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Francisco Pelsaert.

Additional Information:

  • Father Anthony Monserrate visited India during Akbar’s reign as part of the Jesuit mission.
  • Niccolao Manucci came much later during the time of Shah Jahan and Aurangzeb.
  • Francois Vernier visited India during the later Mughal period, especially under Aurangzeb.

question:
Who among the following foreign travellers discussed in detail the diamonds and diamond mines of India?

IAS, 2018
solution:
• The foreign traveler who provided a detailed account of diamonds and diamond mines of India was Jean-Baptiste Tavernier, a French jeweller and traveler.
  • He visited India six times between 1630 and 1668, during the reigns of Shah Jahan and Aurangzeb.
  • Tavernier wrote extensively about the diamond trade, particularly the famous Golconda diamond mines, which were a major source of the world's diamonds at the time.
  • His book, "Travels in India", includes first-hand descriptions of mines, the process of diamond extraction, and the commercial trade network.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Jean-Baptiste Tavernier.

Additional Information:

  • Tavernier is also known for carrying many diamonds back to Europe, including the legendary Tavernier Blue, which later became the Hope Diamond.
  • He interacted with Mughal nobles and was allowed access to view royal treasures.
  • His accounts are valued for their economic and commercial observations rather than political insights.
